text: Prof Thomas Gordon FRSE (1714-1797) was a philosopher, mathematician and antiquarian. He was Professor of Humanity at King's College in Aberdeen. He was a co-founder of the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 1783. ==Life== He was the son of Prof George Gordon, Professor of Hebrew at King's College, Aberdeen. His grandfather, also George Gordon was Principal of the College in 1684. Thomas attended University of Aberdeen, graduating MA in 1731. He thereafter held various positions at the College from Regent to Professor of Greek and Philosophy. He was a member of the Aberdeen Philosophical Society from 1758 to 1773.http://calms.abdn.ac.uk/DServe/dserve.exe?dsqServer=Calms&dsqIni;=Dserve.ini&dsqApp;=Archive&dsqCmd;=Show.tcl&dsqDb;=Catalog&dsqPos;=10&dsqSearch;=((text)='robert%20eden%20scott') Here he debated with its founders Prof John Gregory, Prof Robert Trail and Dr David Skene, and other members such as Prof Alexander Gerard. He taught Robert Eden Scott (1770-1811) (later Prof R E Scott), his grandson, at the College. He died on 11 March 1797.The Scots Magazine vol 59 ==Family== His second daughter Margaret died in 1797.Gentlemans Magazine and Chronicle 1797, p.531 His daughter Anna married Rev. Andrew Brown (d.1805).http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~hou01771 His daughter Elizabeth was the mother of Robert Eden Scott. ==References== Category:1714 births Category:1797 deaths Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh Category:18th-century British philosophers Category:18th-century Scottish writers Category:Alumni of the University of Aberdeen Category:Moral philosophers Category:People from Aberdeen Category:Philosophers of mind Category:Philosophers of religion Category:Scottish essayists Category:Scottish philosophers Category:18th-century essayists
